NATO is already in full engagement, you cuck. There are several reasons they won’t go further:

1. The equipment they are holding back (tanks, f35 etc.) sucks ass. The husks of maintenance intensive, prone to breaking rocket magnets would be a terrible advertisement campaign for NATO, hence their refusal to send their “modern” equipment that just runs in very controlled environments. See turkey with their Leo’s. Clapped by Milan, fagot and tow.

Same goes for F35 or other modern fighter jets. Most of them won’t leave an airfield due to rain or wind, needing so much maintenance and sore parts, even western nations operating these have use half of their fleet as spare part kits.

3. The Russians have learned to live with superior nato intelligence. They have decided to just make up for it by loss of human life. They don’t care. Ultimately every war is about making someone unwilling to sacrifice life further through the use of life ending technology. Russia has shown that it doesn’t care. It will send troops at you by the millions no matter what you throw at them. NATO can’t compete.

TL;DR The Ukraine war is as far as NATO is willing to go. They would lose a direct confrontation politically and on the ballot box, their equipment would be demystified as the trash it is. Most doesn’t even work in peace time (NH90, Puma, Tiger, Leo 2, Challenger, Brandburg class frigates, Dolphin class suns) and they don’t have the men willing to die for globohomo.

>>56686903
How long your going out for, or how far out, should make a pretty big difference.
Ive got 3 tiers of shit i bring:
Belts Kits: (Picrel) I bring this shit for every outing, no matter how short.
Buggout/Survival bag: (not shown) a rather small backpack filled with survival items, this can be a failsafe for daytrips that are kinda far away.
Backpacking Bag: (not shown) A large backpack filled with camping items, but my buggout bag can fit inside it too. This is for overnighters not daytrips.

It doesnt hurt to be a little overprepared, hence why my belts kits has rudimentary shelter, ways to clean water and cook foods etc. Its currently missing a first aids kit though, i really should correct that.
Note; this shit is a work in progress, and they always should be, your needs and situations may change and Will be different than mine, i am open to constructive criticism here.
Also not shown is some shit i stuff in my pockets.

The Northern Alliance was a bunch of different warlords, many of them enemies and rivals. The NATO-backed Kabul regime was the same thing. The relatives of politicians and the warlords were running most of the opium trade. The Afghan Taliban taxed existing poppy farmers in areas they controlled or contested, but they never grew or traded in it themselves.

Giving any power to the warlords and their allies, without NATO holding it together, would have just resulted in a civil war between them. That doesn't hurt AQ either, they would have thrived on it. The reason the Afghan Taliban formed in the first place was because of the ensuing civil war in the first half of the 1990s after the Soviets left. The IEA ended the civil war by taking most of the cities and the south/east.

There's violence now (from ISK and NRF) but its far less than during the US occupation, or during the first half of the 1990s. Any AQ activity in Afghanistan has been irrelevant since the mid 2010s. Since they couldn't implement Salafism, they and ISIS have focused on West Asia and Africa instead since the late 2000s and early 2010s.

The IEA also crushed most of ISK in the late 2010s whereas the former Kabul regime let them run wild, partly to blame their attacks on the Taliban and partly to keep the US staying longer in Afghanistan. The YPG/SDF is basically pulling the same shit in Northeast Syria but ISIS is not a viable threat in the north because you have rival Jihadists and SNA strongholds, Turkey, and even Iran, Russia and Assad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56714746
It's a speed-of-cut thing, the same reason firefighters most frequently use 72cc+ saws like the 460/461/462. The displacement is necessary to keep the chain speed up when they're "misusing" the saw. Put a carbide chain on it and you'll rapidly cut through anything short of foot-thick masonry at the cost of a ruined chain and maybe bar damage + drive system wear. For masonry there's actually the 462 Rock Boss but the times you'd need that vs a breaching charge seems exceptionally rare.
Smaller electric saws may be an answer in the future thanks to the constant torque output. There's 40cc equivalents available now, a 55-62cc equivalent might have the necessary power in a better package. We've already had one fire station evaluate the battery cut-off saws with similar impressions.
t. Stihl mechanic/dealer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56715283
>company wants to switch to battery tools
That's where the industry is going, so much regulatory and social pressure to change has all the manufacturers' R&D going into battery and electronic platforms. Clearest sign of the end of an era for gas power equipment, Honda discontinued production of their lawnmowers and California-compliant generators for 2023.

The battery stuff is handy but there's definite flaws still, especially for professional users who aren't impressed by the ease of starting and simplified "fuel" requirements the way homeowners are. Durability and reliability is the biggest one, they can't be treated the way owners/operators expect of gas equipment. The battery tools fail without warning instead of running rough, blink lights expecting people to have read and remember the owner's manual to decipher what it means, and are hard to fix even for a dealer. Purchase costs being 2-3 times higher doesn't help.
I hate the Husqvarna consumer line in particular because they're otherwise good premium tools that might as well be disposable if it breaks out of warranty. Stihl at least provides detailed electrical schematics for the technicians and stocks an adequate selection of replacement parts at sensible prices. Was amazed to fix an 11 year old MSE 250 months back, the faulty switch module was still available like you'd expect of gas parts.

5.7 out of a 16" barrel is pulling better velocity than 5.56 out of a 16" barrel. A 16" P90 is shorter than a 10" barrel AR. If compactness and performance out of shorter barrels is a consideration, P90 is something to look at. It's short barrel performance beats 5.56 performance out of short barrels (16" is short for velocity dependent .20 cal rounds) and the overall package is extremely space efficient. Even the mag placement is to allow max capacity in a balanced package. It's a fucking highly overlooked design that unfortunately will blow away in the wind soon like the FS2000 (which was not a good design imo, but shows FN will nuke production of something if it's not selling).

Just really here to vent if I'm being honest. But your situations might help me think clearly about mine. So post yours as well.

> Be literally yesterday
> I drive an old 69 F-250 with a 3-speed column, things literally the OPPOSITE of fast
> Live in a predominately black neighborhood
> I'm taking the old girl off-roading, I'm leaving my apartment that has dirt parking lots (live in the deep desert)
> There is a vehicle turning left as he's exiting the same apartment complex.
> I'm turning right so i go over some rough terrain on his right side. At about 5-10mph
> Think nothing of it, as I'm just simply doing what i always do.
> Fast forward 1.5hrs later after a good day out off-roading and exploring
> As I'm pulling into my parking spot i see a huge 350-400lbs melanin enriched individual waiting by my spot, absolutely staring me down.
> Ignore him, and proceed to park.
> As I'm exiting my vehicle he waddles over
> "Why the fuck you try to run me off the road!?"
> Confused I say "Because I went around you!?"
> He immediately retorts "You're lucky to be alive right now" if it wasn't for my pops, you'd be dead right now, he saved your life"
> I say, "really for driving around you?"
> Starts just rambling about how I have no idea how lucky I am right now, literally follows me to my front door all while still mouthing off
> I'm just watching his hands the whole time. Ready to draw like I've practiced a hundred times over
> He ends up just leaving, but I seen him hanging around the parking lot at night. Neighbors confirmed her doesn't even live here.

So that's about it guys, it's a developing story, hasn't even been 24 hrs since this incident. Any input would be appreciated.

posts.name: Lubeanon
posts.com:
>>56699554
Wipe with breakfree CLP. I do not know what finish it got but smooth finish means oil cant penetrate and all kinds of contact to dry fabric, metall... soaks up the protection film or demages is which creats a starting point for rust when its not relubed. Rust also comes when you touch it, you add salts and remove oil at the same time, so its getting a bit ineffectiv against humidity. Pic related rust sensitiv steel, without demaging the oil layer you can pretty much spray water on it for a fucking month... (pic is 10days). CLP only got a failure after 6h at the top because it failed to penetrate into imperfections which caused water to penetrate and rust since day 1. So the most important rule is making a rag with CLP to wipe after using, filling up scratches/dry spots to avoid a rust starting spots (they grow)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56699806
Mostly pretty good. The only finish issue I can find is this area on the frame. It could just be wear from test firing and racking but it looks odd for that. The grips are also not particularly symmetrical though I can't actually feel the difference between sides. The front sight isn't perfectly centered but it's close enough that it's not noticeable unless I'm feeling it and it won't matter anyway unless the POI is off.

The slide has basically no horizontal play on the frame and a little vertical play. In contrast my M9 has basically no vertical play and a little horizontal play and the CZ-75 has a bit more play both horizontally and vertically.

I like the trigger but I've never even seen another Hi-Power let alone fired/dry-fired one to compare it with. The take-up is very short like my 1911. It's not really as crisp as the 1911 or Beretta/Sig SA but the creep is predictable so if I'm taking my time after hitting the initial wall I can pull a tiny bit more and get to the actual wall, at which point the break is nice and crisp. Either way it's a lot nicer than the CZ SA.

I won't actually know until I fire it enough but the magazine feeds and the extractor extracts when hand cycling.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56703093
>7 whole yards!
Kek, sorry don't mean to be an asshole but go shoot some B8s at 25.

You're probably having a trigger control issue with the glock. Are you shooting it like a rifle with the middle of the final pad of your finger for maximum control? This is actually wrong for pistols and makes it more difficult to pull straight back and avoid disturbing the gun. Before I knew this I had trouble with the factory glock trigger too, really just the shape of the shoe. The way it comes to a a point in the center, made it nearly impossible for me not to push the muzzle slightly left when I was doing rifle style trigger control. Replaced it with a flat faced shoe and that fixed the problem. Now that I do it correctly and shove my finger in the trigger guard as far as it goes it doesn't matter though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56704228
92X will fit any full size 92/M9 holster that accommodates a rail.
There's a lot of rare variants out there that even include a rail but most likely the ones you will see that should work:
>92A1/96A1, 92X (includes RDO, Performance not Performance Defensive), M9A1/3/4, LTT models
Centurion/Compact holsters don't work since the slide is too short.
Threaded barrel holsters (e.g. M9A4) will work but may be a half inch longer than necessary.
>knowledge drop
Parts are literally 100% interchangeable even to the earliest Beretta 92 with exception to older slides won't work on frames on 92FS onward due to the cutout for the oversized hammer pin.
E.g. you can take a slide assembly from an M9A4 and drop it on a 92S and it will work but not vice-versa.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56705099
>trigger guard
That's a caveat worth mentioning. Squared or "combat" trigger guards (e.g. 92FS, M9A4) won't work in specific rounded ones (e.g. 92S, 92X) but the rounded ones will work in the squared ones.
But otherwise the only gun parts that matter as to whether a 92 holster is compatible is
>slide length: full size vs Centurian/Compact
>barrel length: flush (92X), normal (most, a la 92FS) or threaded (M9A3/4)
>sight height: normal vs suppressor height
>dust cover rail or not
>trigger guard shape
>cut for RDO if applicable
Possible exception to mag release. Even consider these changes and it ought to even apply to clones like Girsan and Taurus models

If you're purely looking for cosmetics, you can go with the obvious things such as grips.
Beretta also offers various colors of aluminum triggers for the 92 series on their site. Otherwise you could put something on the accessory rail, but most people will probably have a TLR-1 or X300 light, so that wouldn't really make it stand out from the rest.

In short, you have a lot of options with the gun and making it your own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56708583
Grips. Not a lot of options for vertecs (92x) in the wood department but my LS grips fit.

You want trigger work?

LTT optimized trigger bar for 70 or the whole Beretta Xtreme S trigger group for 120 on europtic or Midwest gun works when they are in stock (sorry I bought one) or the whole LTT trigger kit for 175.

Personally the trigger bar, trigger return spring, and the hammer are the main things that change your double action pull. Everything else in the trigger job in a bag or the Xtreme S is diminishing returns, except the hammer - that’s important for SA pulls. The match hammer and the upgraded trigger bar makes for a really really short and light SA pull, it should be fitted so the firing pin block is fully functional- without fitting the block is already slightly moved without any trigger movement. The Xtreme S kit is nice because it has a better IMO trigger profile (you can’t buy the trigger separately unless you want gaudy colors like blue).

The Wilson or Wolff trigger return spring kits seem to work, they make the trigger return spring a literal linear movement (look at a picture of one) and feel linear with no stacking. The installation and removal is easier than stock. They last longer than the stock one as well - stock trigger return springs must be changed out every 5k rounds.

If you want a compensator, get the Jarvis one. Not the PMM.

posts.sub: /QTDDTOT/ - Questions That Don't Deserve Their Own Threads
posts.com:
I can't for the life of me find a O/U that I can aim consistently with, give me a semi-automatic for clay shooting and I'm roughly hitting on a good day for normal Trap shooting 23/25 shots, but with an O/U I'm hitting roughly 18/25 on average.
Though I'm absolutely struggling with Olympic Skeet where especially on Station 1 and 2, I can hit the high bird fine, but by the time I reorientate myself to the low bird it's usually either just high enough to hit or already on the ground by the time I have eyes on.
Any tips Anons?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56711389
The O/Us you've tried don't fit you. There's something wrong, either the length of pull or the drop of the stock. If you have a gun nearby it's fairly easy to check the drop.
Pick some point in the distance you can focus on and concentrate your vision on that point. Hold your shotgun and then quickly raise it up to your shoulder as though you are going to shoot--basically pretend that whatever spot you picked is a clay. Concentrate your vision on that spot, not the gun. Now, after you've raised the gun up, what do you see when the rib is in your vision? If you can see the rear of the rib but not the bead then your stock has too much drop and the result is that the barrels are pointing slightly down. And vice-versa: if you can see the front bead and the whole length of the rib, sort of like what a runway looks like from the perspective of a landing plane, there is not enough drop and as a result the barrels are pointing slightly high. When the drop is correct you can see the bead but not the rib because you will be looking perfectly straight down the rib. The same thing applies left-to-right: When you bring up the gun it should point straight away from you. If it wants to lean a little left or right then the "cast" is wrong.

>>56712244
NBC suit is not so hard counter as you think.
First what type of suit?
There is classic cheap old style rubber suits. Problem you can't wear them all day in warm weather, they can't let sweat out and too hot. But puting suit after attack happened may be too late, you put suit over already contaminated uniform and it not gonna help. Comblock mostly issued such typenof suits.
There also more modern filtration type suits that have breathable fabric with filter built in (like gas mask filter). They can be worn as uniform in ready to attack mode. Much better. NATO uses such types of suits. But suit only good for several weeks of using, after wear and tear makes them lose protection.
Another thing, chemical weapons contaminate also gear, vehicles etc. You can't really function in the field under chemical contamination. Your are supposed to leave contaminated area, decontaminate gear or just abandon it it can't be decontaminated. If you hit say in defensive position and can't fall back due to tactical reasons eventually you get enough dosages even when using NBC gear.
Highly toxic chemicals like nerve agents are hard to cope with. It's not your granddaddy's mustard gas

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because chemical weapons have never been nearly as effective as we'd like. The idea of it being some taboo red line that can't be crossed is partially true, but more than that, they're just not actually that useful for battlefield applications. To effectively use them (regardless of their potency) you need a pretty precise location of the enemy, a fairly accurate delivery mechanism (shells or drones), and good weather. Even then, youre releasing an area affecting weapon that immediately dissipates into the air upon release, can be countered with gas masks or suits, and if long lasting, makes pushing into that area a pain. And if you have the capabilities to deliver gas effectively, explosives do it even better.

There's a reason world war I was the only war where chemical weapons were used on the battlefield in conventional armies, and all sides figured out it wasn't a war winning weapon. Adolf didn't use it not because it would have been some moral line or unthinkable last straw, but rather be a use it wouldn't have won the war, and would have just invited the other side to use them too.

tl;dr they're more trouble than they're worth. Too finicky on the battlefield, too politically costly internationally, and even when used effectively, they don't win wars

>makes less noise which is a plus for limited range options
>thus also being great for home defense without hearing protection
>also great for suppressor use
among many other pro points not listed
so what's not to like and not to understand ?

>What’s the hurdle?
That each tax stamp corresponds to one specific serialized item you're buying/own (e.g., sbr, suppressor, etc.). Without the serial number of the item for the tax stamp, authorities would not be able to verify the gun or suppressor you have is the one that the tax stamp corresponds to.

Here's the process I (and most likely all of the NFA item owners on /k/) have gone through for a Form 1
> buy base item, i.e. KP9 pistol
> fill out and submit Form1 eForm under trust
> wait
> once stamp is approved, purchase stock
> attach stock
...and you are done. I have only done this twice (KP9 SBR and KS12 SBS)

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56703441
I should've clarified that using a trust is not necessary, I personally chose to do it for a variety of reasons, a few being:
> associating all of my NFA items with a legal entity and not my own name
> allows me to easily transfer ownership of the NFA items associated with the trust to my wife or children as a part of my will in the event of my death
> by associating an NFA item with a trust, in the event of my death, those items will bypass probate court and their existence will never become public record
> adds the ability to name additional "Trustees ", people allowed to possess and handle those items without legal repurcussions
Also NFA approval times for trusts are generally quicker (21 and 27 days for my two eForm Form1's)
Those are the reasons I did it, hope this was informative

Now we consider the bullet in it's path and write down all the forces acting on it: projecting on the x axis (in a bullet cartesian system) Rx = -kx^2 - mgcos theta Ry = -mgsintheta + Lift where lift is given by 1/2 rho Cl x'^2 A with Cl being the coefficient of life and A the area of the bullet. Finally we substitute the resultants in the Newton's first law (or second idk) and we get Rx = mx'' and Ry = my'' you can have fun solving the differential equation for x substituting 0.5 m x'^2 = ek V where V is the volume of the bullet as ek is a intensive quantity and as you may find out, the lift term is an order of magnitude smaller than the gravity of the bullet ending up with a resultant headed to the negative y which you can port into the real word by writing y = y' cos theta and thus the main component of the acceleration is headed downward. >>56703834
Yes the ATF has long been known to go after people by claiming they have "constructive intent" to manufacture unregistered NFA items. This is the reasoning they're using to persecute people who bought solvent traps and other Form 1 silencer kits. Basically if you own something like an MP5 pistol, and also own the stock for it, they will say you had the intent to attach it even if it's not actually attached when they arrest you. The only way around it is if you have another MP5 that has already been SBRed to maintain plausible deniability. There's a reason why retailers never sell pistols and stocks together as kits. Beware of anyone selling a pistol and stock together secondhand, since it could be a sting operation. It was just recently discovered that the ATF was selling Rarebreed FRTs on fuddbroker as a sting operation while the court case over their legality was still ongoing.

Why are Humans attracted to war? Through all the bloodshed, pain and suffering. Through all of the horrors and tragedy, through all of the death and fear. >Warfare activates the same parts of the mind as team sports.

Yes, and? Again, it´s using natural instincts for a purpose that is pretty artificial. The logistics of moving Sherman tanks across oceans or the mathematics and geometry involved in firing artillery at targets 18km away may be the final product of honing a natural instinct for artificial purposes, but they don´t really seem all that similar to you playing some ball games with your friends in preschool, and any attempt to equate them is going to sound like you´re stretching shit too far.

>People will actively seek out conflict if they think it benefits their group. Ex: niggers starting gang wars over petty shit.

We don´t do warfare because we are naturally inclined to it. We do it because our rulers trap us into it with propaganda and the law. If it didn´t require a nation to do war, we´d be doing it all the time, everywhere in the globe, regardless of political circumstances, like any other social behaviors.

If you decide to remove the auto bolt block that was welded on the back of the receiver, it makes the ATF extra fuckin nervous you might sneeze and make it into a machine gun, so they might shoot your dog preemptively.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56680794

Just guessing here but a combination of things. The pocket clip looks like it is probably awful, plus it has a totally unnecessary logo.
The VG-10 billboard is obnoxiously large. VG-10 is decent steel but it's more of a weeb kitchen knife steel than a pocket knife steel; you want it on a high flat grind that you can easily remove material from, not a low pseudo-scandi-whatever-the-fuck-that-is. Likewise you don't really look for that much thickness out to the tip on a sheepsfoot... this is closing in on being a prybar.
The carry profile isn't as rectangular/slim as you would normally expect from a knife like that.
Lanyard hole is in poor taste. Flipper tab looks meh.

Just a lot of little things that add up to a knife that nobody should want.

Flips do it because in the naked combat icepick grip has less reach and has more chances to glance off the ribcage. Because flips still do first blood duelling.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56680749
Sleipner is a tool steel. I like calling it a budget version of CPM 3V. It has some corrosion resistance, decent toughness and it's very easy to sharpen. Edge retention should be somewhere between 14C28N and VG10 due to low carbide volume. Nowhere near CPM 3V and its vanadium carbides.

Sometimes people say that Sleipner is some kind of D2. Those people are retarded, it's an entirely different steel.

posts.name: Anonymous

>M-55S - T-55 modernization developed by the STO RAVNE company and engineers of the Israeli company Elbit. Slovenia modernized 30 T-55 tanks in the inventory of its armed forces. The last T-55 was modernized to the M-55S standard in May 1999. The original 100mm tank gun was replaced by the NATO-standard 105mm one with a thermal sleeve. The armour protection of the tank was improved considerably by attaching Rafael ERA blocks to the hull and the turret. A digital ballistic computer was installed in order to improve the fire control system (FCS). The gunner has the Fotona SGS-55 two-axis stabilized day-and-night sight with an integral laser rangefinder. In addition to the integral optic sight the commander has the Fotona COMTOS-55 sight with an independent line-of-sight stabilization, which allows him to acquire targets and lay the gun independently if required. The driver has the Fotona CODRIS combined day/night observation periscope. The LIRD-1A laser illumination warning receiver was mated with front-mounted IS-6 smoke grenade launchers (of which there are six in two clusters, one per side of the turret) and can be automatically activated in an emergency. Modernization of the V-12 diesel engine resulted in an increase in power from 520hp to 600hp. The running gear has rubber side skirts and the tank was outfitted with new rubber and metal tracks. Improvements were also made to the communications aids.[42] In October 2022, Slovenia gave 28 M-55S to Ukraine; Germany provides 40 transport vehicles to Slovenia, as Prime Minister Robert Golob and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz arranged some weeks ago. The vehicles will also serve for protection and rescue.[184]

>>56707334
No, you only need 2 for triangulation.
Point A is the cause, point B is an observer, point C is an observer.
Both observers make a straight line towards where they saw/heard/detected the cause, and where those two line meet is point A.

It is the 21st century. For more than a dozen years The Monke has sat immobile in his bunker in the Kremlin. He is the Master of Ruskind by the will of banan, and master of a million vatniks by the might of his inexhaustible corruption. Yet even in his decrepit state, the Monke continues his eternal vigilance. Mighty rustbuckets cross the drone-infested miasma of the Black Sea, the only warm-water port to distant lands, their way lit by the Copenomican, the psychic manifestation of the Monke's will. Vast armies give battle in his name in uncounted villages. Greatest amongst his soldiers are the Veh Deh Veh, the Blyat Marines, vodka-addled super-warriors. Their comrades in arms are legion: the Rosgvardija and countless PMC forces, the ever vigilant FSB and the priests of the Russian Orthodoxy to name only a few. But for all their multitudes, they are barely enough to hold off the ever-present threat from Ukies, democracy, prosperity - and worse.

To be a vatnik in such times is to be one amongst untold millions. It is to live in the most dysfunctional and corrupt regime imaginable. These are the tales of those times. Forget the power of technology and science, for so much has been embezzled, never to be re-aquired. Forget the promise of progress and understanding, for in the grim dark present there is only banan. Tall = see farther

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56698803
Naval artillery can shoot over the visual horizon, but you need to be able to see things back in the day to aim at them, the higher up you place your rangefinding and fire direction equipment, the farther over the horizon you can see and thus the farther you can shoot.

Its all about seeing the opposing ships first and shooting at them first, assuming similar levels of crew skill and gun quality the guy with the taller mast is going to spot enemy ships over the horizon first and shoot at them first and getting the first rounds down range is a natural advantage, since your crew will get first and likely second slavo off without taking return fire and also the other guy is going to have to do everything with incoming fire now, making evasive turns worrying about damage control measures if he takes any hits.

The natural extension of this thinking is to carry and launch spotting aircraft to see even farther and to call fire corrections from a safe and superior vantage point.

That surface engagement never happened, Fuso for example was sunk in a battle that both Yamato and Musash ran from after receiving superficial hits, because they simply could not risk losing them.

Even though the primary reason for the height of the pagoda mast was to increase the height of the primary rangefinder to increase the range at which they can see and engage other ships the pagoda mast also served another function which was to increase working space within the main superstructure without increasing its footprint much which would impact other elements of the ship like machinery and main armament placement (especially in Fuso and Yamashiro's case). Additionally even though the pagoda masts of ships like Fuso and Yamashiro look insanely tall in comparison to other capital ships of the period, it's deceptive and there's not actually that much difference in height when compared to ships like the North Carolina and South Dakota-classes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56708148
>what was the point of the half aircraft carrier?
To provide some semblance of air cover for other ships in a fleet. After Repulse and Prince of Wales were sunk in December 1941 by land based aircraft it became increasingly apparent that ships at sea without air cover were increasingly vulnerable. Since Japan lost four fleet carriers not long after at Midway their own resources were somewhat stretched thin. Ise and Hyuuga were convenient for conversion to aviation battleship since they were already somewhat dated and Hyuuga was already in a bad way with her X turret having been damaged to the point where it was considered unrepairable and removed with the barbette simply capped over.
>what was the point of the half aircraft carrier?
Warship design is always a game of balancing with regards to firepower, speed, protection, size and cost as well as taking into account naval treaties and physical limitations such as canal width for passage and the availability of suitable sized docks and facilities. As naval guns got larger and technology developed it became apparent that generally speaking, larger but fewer main battery rifles was preferable to a more numerous but smaller calibre arrangement. It's also worth taking into account that naval gunnery is notoriously wild when talking accuracy and the ranges of engagement involved. By adding more main battery rifles and throwing more shit at the wall you improve your chances somewhat of actually hitting something (though that's not always the case, see HMS Agincourt at Jutland). With innovations in radar and fire control it could be seen to be beneficial to go for larger guns rather than more of them, if you hit what you're shooting at you're likely to do more damage. That's not the be all and end all of the matter but it's a very quick rundown.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56680081
NTA, I've used dacron pillow stuffing and also "cream of wheat" cereal as filler with zero issues. One application was loading .450 Nitro Express for a Thompson Encore. I've also used it when making nitro-for-black loads for .500 BPE and .300 Sherwood. The risk that I had heard was that it could theoretically leave some residue behind in the barrel which would then act as a bore obstruction. I was always super careful to inspect the barrel after every shot to see if there was any residue left behind but I never saw any evidence of that. Also keep in mind that only a tiny bit of dacron or cotton is needed to do the job. You don't cram it in there like you're ramming a muzzleloader, you just use a tiny little bit. A single cotton ball, fluffed up, would be enough to load many cartridges. I've been using the same bag of pillow stuffing for years and it still looks like it's mostly full, the amount used in any one cartridge is just a couple of grains. There simply isn't enough material to leave a bore obstruction behind. Not to mention it has massive surface area so I'm sure it all combusts during firing.

>>56680350
You don't. If you're using dacron or cotton you just use a tiny wisp of it, the volume it occupies is negligible. The space the filler occupies is 99.999% empty air, and quickload should treat it as such.
Sometimes I've used hard card wads aka "nitro cards" to take up space in cartridges. Those are incompressible and have non-negligible mass, so I modify the the bullet parameters to account for the extra "length" and mass of the wads.

posts.com: Could somebody with QuickLoad help a brother out? I’m reloading 7x57mm Mauser with .30-06 cases formed down to 7x57. I’m shooting a 140gr Hornady Interlock and would like to use CFE-223. Target velocity is 2,780fps

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56692870
>.30-06 cases formed down to 7x57
Check your case volume, according to GRT it should be 59.70 grains H2O. Also chec that you've got 139s, because 140 grain Interlocks are .277, not 0.284 as they should be for the 7mm.
According to GRT, with a COAL of 77.5mm and a 24 inch barrel, 45.5 grains of CFE-223 should get you right around 2780FPS, with some pressure left over in case you end up short. Note that the bullet is not fully guided in the neck, so you might want to seat it deeper which will increase the pressure but gain some velocity. See for yourself, GRT is free.

>black powder
Literally just fill the case to such a degree that the powder will get moderately compressed when the bullet is seated. Done.

I'm not sure how it is in other countries, but here in Australia (or at least in my state), if you rob a store with an imitation firearm, you'll get done for armed robbery. From a legal perspective, what's important is that you've caused the public and police to *believe* that you have a firearm. While the fact that the firearm wasn't real will probably be taken into account in sentencing, you'll still be charged with "armed robbery".

Either way, if you believe someone has a firearm, in my view you're justified in blowing their head off. This fella might be in a bit of trouble for shooting the felon when he was down, but hopefully Texas lives up to its reputation. Play stupid games, win stupid prizes.

Hey, /k/, I got myself wondering how, and how much terrain really affects modern warafe. For God's sake, all gorilla fighters have pickup trucks with decent suspension that can handle offroading just fine.
How do these different landscapes interfere with attacking, providing advantages or disadvantages to combat tactics and actual combat.
>forests
>jungles
>marshes
>mountains
>plains
>city scapes

I'm taking book suggestions and infographics just fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56710268
What’s a warafe

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56710268
Trucks are cool for getting across terrain. Just like horses. Mounting a bunch of dudes in a truck who dismount to fight is just re-creating dragoon infantry.
You know what the problem with dragoon infantry is? Horses are fragile. They need special food different from what you give to your troops. If the horses get spooked or hit by artillery, your troops can't withdraw. Mounted troops advancing are easier to see coming. Every one of those problems apply to modern technicals, despite them going faster, carrying more men, and being tougher.

>different landscapes
>Jungle
This is fucking murder. It's constantly wet, which means rust and disease. Cutting a road is extremely visible and leads to rapid erosion. Going offroad is slow and incredibly dangerous. Jungle ecosystems are constantly hungry.

>forests
There's a big difference between something like a managed oak or beech forest and an evergreen rainforest, or old-growth timber stands. Some are relatively open and easy to infiltrate through. Wilderness absolutely isn't -- it's full of deadfalls, underground hollows, often poisonous critters like snakes and wasps, and hilariously uneven. Not as hostile as jungle but still very difficult to move quickly through.

>Marshes
moving large numbers of troops through a marsh rapidly degrades the stable areas, unless you're willing to send a bunch of pioneers through to build roads. Again, wet and miserable. Generally less poisonous and hostile than jungles despite being just as disease-riddled. Vees are Right Out. Ambushing is much harder than in wooded/jungle terrain if the enemy has airborne scouting like drones or aircraft.

>mountains
Again, the Rockies or the Alps and the Appalachians are very different questions. The former you're not crossing without a pass or specialized troops, the latter is an annoying obstacle.

>plains, cities
Where everyone wants/expects to fight, just read some books.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56711367
>>The only thing the different tiles offer to the game is a defense modifier that makes different tiles be more costly to conquer. But I wanted more flavor to that.
Jungles: massive movement/attack penalty if the attack isn't made along a river. The defender is not obliged to reveal the number of units he has assigned inside a jungle or forest tile, though he must reveal units to roll dice for them. The player occupying forest tiles must move units from their initial location into the forest, then record any subsequent movements until they are engaged or leave forest terrain.
>mountains, marshes
Maximum limit to the number of dice that can be rolled each turn. Heavy limit to the number of units that can fortify or move through them.
>plains, roads, rivers
Increase reinforcement move distances
>cities
Serve as rallying points for reinforcements, units must start their move within (x) territories of a city on their first turn, where (x) is the size/importance of the city.

It's abstract and a little gamey but it gives a decent level of verisimilitude.

Alright, so I think I should post some updates. Little buddy isn't doing well. For a brief day or two, the increased meds seemed to be working, his liver swelling has gone down more and his eyes were clear and he could see me. Now he's not playing, not eating, not drinking. He lays under the dining room table, his eyesight seems to be bad again. All we could get him to eat was some tuna-flavored tapioca paste that the vet would give him (it's only like 6 calories per tube, so not much), and he drank a small amount of water, but that was on the morning of the 2nd. He's just returned to laying under the table and taking nothing, he feels cold to the touch.
By all accounts, it seems like his liver is failing, and he's probably going to die. We're now looking at an in-home euthanasia service so he doesn't need to leave his home or his family. If the weather in the morning permits, I'm going to bring him outside to the back yard. It's only fair, he's wanted to go out there for the whole of his short little life, and we kept saying he could when he was a little bigger in the spring, lest an owl or hawk grab him. I think now is the time to grant that wish, he won't last that long unless a miracle happens. I don't think he would run if he wanted to anyway.
Thanks for the sympathy and support that you guys have given through this ordeal. I may try to post some videos I have of him later if it's alright. I'm currently posting from work, so when I finally post again it will probably be after he's gone. I'm going to spend what time I have left with the little guy, keeping him company and taking some final vids and pics so I can remember him.

>>56614972
Alright, last update. I took him outside a little before the vet came. He seemed a little confused. Sat with him a little before he decided he wanted to go back inside.
She came and confirmed that it was terminal, it was affecting his eyes and brain, and he was blind. His eyes were open, he just couldn't see anything, wasn't even blinking anymore.
We set him down on his favorite bed, the one he took over from the dogs. Put the bed in front of the Christmas tree, we didn't really have the time or thought to bother taking it down yet. She gave him the shot to put him under, startled him at first but then he began to calm down and go to sleep. We spoke to him and rang his bell as he drifted off (he used to ring a bell to get treats, even when he stopped eating he'd still ring it and purr). She made a few casts of his paw in clay as this happened.
She gave him the last shot after a little after that as we gathered around and patted him softly. He was gone in minutes.
We've all been crying, even before she got here we cried and sat around him. Even my normally stoic dad was bawling his eyes out so hard he was coughing, and this man didn't cry at his own mother's funeral.
I don't know what to do anymore, I feel empty inside. He won't be waiting for me at the bottom stair when I leave for work next weekend. He won't rush to the door to greet me when I come home, I'll never set his bell down for him to ring before he gets his favorite treats again, I'll never hear his sweet little voice call out to me again. I'd rather have died in his stead, he was only a baby. He was born in late summer, and he never lived to see the spring. I feel like I failed him.
I'm sorry there's not a happy end to this story guys. I'd have given anything to give him a few more years of life, I'd melt every gun I own in a huge fire and dump all my ammo in the sea if it meant he would have lived even a few more years. I can always buy more guns, I can't replace him.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56615530
>I feel like I failed him.
You didn't. The day will come when you can accept that.

Something to consider, going into the future, not for anytime "too soon." I've buried about a dozen friends now, and these things helped out. Eventually.

You can honor the memory of your friend by adopting another who needs a home. There are millions, and you can give at least one a chance that they didn't have. It hurts, but they are also a comfort.

Something I learned was that a single cat gets a bit neglected, even in a house with best intentions. Humans just get wrapped up in things and distracted by Important Life Stuff. So, if you have the option, get more than one cat. Two works if that's already stretching your resources & space and you can still do it, but three seems to be an optimum. They have each other to explore & play and socialize with, humans present or not. They really are highly social, especially if their humans interact with them and show them how.

Two often work together, but the relationship can become one-sided. I've found that three create an unstable dynamic so that one doesn't dominate another & bully. No matter any conflict two get into, the third provides a distraction that breaks a pattern of regular abuse of one against another. You need to guide them, and be attentive should one personality just not work out for Reasons.

Anyway, the younger the better. They grow up as if they are brothers & sisters. How you teach them young will imprint for their entire lives, so put extra effort in early.

Cheers and good on ya' for having a huge heart. Peace to you and all of yours.

>>56647505
>cat just turned 1 a month or so ago, is that still young enough to get along with other cats
Yes, entirely. You'll need to do some research on introducing a new cat into a house that already has cats. There's do's & dont's to make it comfortable & happy for everyone.

First tip: new cat(s) should be younger than the older cat. There is automatic seniority dominance, which can be groomed into a relationship even if the dynamics change later. Any cat under ~3 years old is still largely a kitten & can be easily subverted with food, play, food, attention, play, food, more attention ... They tend to accept the newcomer as a playmate if the humans set the environment.

The established resident has run of the house, for example. Bring the newcomer in & they get locked in a room the first 24 hours before they meet so they get used to each other in the same house & their scents. For the first few months, until they clearly get along without harm to each other, the established senior gets the house, the newcomer gets put into a room if things get a bit spicy between them.

Get them eating together, do not allow them to eat each others' food, at least the first 6 months. Keep them close to each other, feed them at the same time, talk to both, give both attention, separate them (gently, no drama) if either infringes on the other.

Get them to play together. In the same room at first. Play with the senior cat first, draw the other in. I would walk around the room dragging 2 strings. Each would take their own string at first, after a few sessions they figured out playtime and even started wrestling each other without fighting.

Your cat is very young. This is the best time to introduce a new cat the same age or slightly younger. By the time they are 2 they will be like littermates for life. There are exceptions, but do your part and it's very rare. I brought a 6 month kitten into a house with a 7 year old cat. It worked out fine, but I put a lot into it up front.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56647505 >>56647880 --> CT'd -->
One thing you can take advantage of is that your cat is already a girl. She will be highly territorial. Bringing in another girl is not the optimal situation here, so try to bring in a younger male, maybe 6-8 or ~10 months. She will establish dominance, but will have mothering instinct triggered (very strong in cats) & set her littermate senses set tingling ... plus the spice of a sexy young male. This is probably your best option for best chances to succeed, especially if this is the first time you are attempting it.

Your current cat will have feelings on the issue. Be sensitive to them, talk to her about them, give her reassurance that she's still the prettiest girl, give extra grooming, playtime, attention in general. It'll smooth things out greatly for the first few weeks & months. The newcomer interrupts, give him attention, but don't stop giving the most attention to your good girl.

You are playing the role of the third cat I mentioned. Break up bad behavior patterns with firm authority, encourage good behavior patterns. My 7 year old always slept with me (a boy). The new kitten (also a boy) insisted on sleeping with us. The older cat objected & pouted, would walk away, but always come back because it was HIS bed. I fell asleep every night with one of them on each side of me, petting both of them until I fell asleep. They would both calm down & purr, so they could hear & smell each other but not see or touch. A month later they were falling asleep leaning against each other, in bed with me or otherwise.

The younger cat had huge kitten energy & bullied the older cat. I would distract him with playtime & put him in a (dark) room to give the older cat relief. Not a situation as likely for you, but could help in some cases.

Food discipline is important. They get the exact same thing at the exact same time. Nobody gets treats unless everybody gets treats. You can relax that later as appropriate.

You're building a pride.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56704355
t. retard who thinks springs wear out from being compressed rather than the compression/extension cycle.
The brass stretches slightly during firing for obturation, and then is supported by the chamber walls. For reloading, you often need to re-form the case so it will hold the bullet. It's this stretching during firing, then re-forming, then stretching again, repeated over and over, that wears out the neck of the brass case and causes splits.
OP is suggesting using a paper wad when seating the bullet in the brass case, so that it only gets stretched once during initial firing, and then stays in the wider position where it can be supported by the chamber walls, to avoid this.
>>56704011
>Cases good. Take heat out of system
This is inarguably true, but I honestly wonder how important it is. I know some people really enjoy rapid-firing through mag after mag and do heat up their guns enough that cookoff could be a concern, but you can't tell me there's no way around that. Hell, even if the solution is fudd-style "one round per 5 seconds" limits, there's still a niche for that. I'd buy a caseless bolt action.

Okay let me spoonfeed you retard
first watch this video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=luZtP3SWPO4

This video shows you how to install a AR-15 barrel and the process on how to remove it is the reverse. Simply take your AR-15 and put it into the receiver vice block and into the vice. Make sure your gastube has been removed and place your barrel wrench into the delta ring assembly. Remember lefty loosely righty tightly so you want to turn left/counter clockwise with your torque wrench. Once loosen you can pull off the delta ring assembly and pull out your barrel. If your still struggling please seek a gunsmith/AR armorer to help you.

If the HP bullets are driven at actual 10mm velocities the petals will likely fold back on the bullet or break off negating any expansion. Don't (you) me with exceptions to this. If I wanted to roll the dice on hollow point expansion I'd just carry a 9mm.

Not that guy, but your options are basically limited to private land (if you or someone you know has enough away from houses/businesses) or public land (innawoods, basically). Nobody's going to tell you where their public land shooting spot is, because every time it happens, every retard with a gun starts shooting there and completely shits the place up and gets it shut down by the cops. I shoot in the woods in a small spot with a natural 50 foot berm, and I'll never tell anyone where it is for that reason.

It's a shame all the private outdoor ranges are owned by boomers and have long as fuck waiting lists. NH is such a gun friendly state, but there's nowhere to shoot if you don't live near some substantial forest or aren't willing to wander around for hours in the woods trying to find a suitable spot.

Even on public land (at least in my area) you have to be careful, because there are a lot of well traveled trails, so you need to be as far away as possible from them not to spook the shitlibs going for a "nature trail walk," otherwise you're going to have some recent CT or NY transplants hysterically calling 911 to report someone shooting an "assault rifle" in the woods. So far, either no one's called the cops on me, or the cops laughed at them if they did.

>>56706111
>If their homeland sucks, like Canada, they should make it better instead of swarming better countries

Many times, this takes nearly an entire lifetime or longer. The majority of people in any country at any given time are not going to just live a shit life so the next generations can have it better. America became the behemoth it is due to industrial might because the things people gained from having massive industry were things they wanted. You're also faced with the fact that culturally (for lack of a better term) such tasks are just a no-go in some places; no matter how much of a hard-working well-meaning guy you are, if you're from Afghanistan for example it will always be a terrible place to live in nearly every metric because one man or a small handful cannot change an entire nation on their own, especially with everyone else's priorities and wants being actively detrimental. And that's something that would take several lifetimes, if that, to change. Most people are fond of their homeland, but aren't willing to live a life of toil for the hope that maybe the next citizen has it better.

So they'll hop the fence, board that raft, marry that fat pig for a Green Card, whatever they need as long as the pros outweigh the risk and they're capable enough. I know some say "no immigration of any sort forever", but that would not only be impossible politically, it would cripple the country in several ways. People come over on business all the time, they come over for tourism, they legally work seasonally doing shit jobs Americans won't for basically no money; you could avoid them abusing this and immigrating illegally by making such things verboten, but you would annihilate the tourism industry overnight, oranges would be $5 each or something equally ridiculous (that or the collapse of a lot of rural America), and international trade would take a massive nosedive. All you can really do is filter out the least-driven an least-able, but some always will.

1. Punch out disk
2. Center disk on hole with desired od
3. Use bushing to center undersized punch
4. Press through
5. Repeat as necessary
lube and annealing where necessary ofc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56710375
Modern smokeless is heavily-washed pure cellulose boiled in two very nasty acids, then the excess acid is pulled off and it's mixed with nitroglycerine and other chemicals before being shaped to pretty precise dimensions. The larger the batch, the more even the conversion is and the more consistent the resulting powder. You may also notice nitroglycerine there. It is not your friend. Neither is simmering nitric and sulfuric acids, which both have explosive vapors. If you don't feel like a multibase powder, you still need to simmer up a nice big pot of nitric acid. And for best results with single-base powders like Guncotton, you need to let the resulting powder age in small batches far away from UV light, moisture, and ambient heat. At which point it >probably< won't explode on its own and has time for the less pure celluloses to react. It'll still have unpredictable pressures, they'll just be a lot more even.
Then there's primers, which are MOTHERFUCKERS to synthesize safely. They involve handling a shitload of highly-reactive lead compounds, or vile corrosive salts that have a bad habit of making things they're spilled on explosive/autoigniting later.

>>56705752
1. The cummerbund was designed exclusively for fats. (I guess they know their market?)
2. The shoulder pads/buckles were poorly designed and interfere with shouldering and firing.
3. Unreasonably heavy. Almost a pound heavier than the comparably-specced First Spear Strandhogg. (2.5 vs. 1.7 pounds.) Nearly as heavy as the old-school LBT 6094, which is much more ruggedly built.
4. That stupid zipper is exposed and is gonna break. If you're going to have zippers on a fucking plate carrier, you at least need to cover it with a flap of nylon.
5. Too much padding.
> B-but it's comfy
Yeah, if you wear your carrier for five minutes. If you wear it for hours at a time, the padding adds substantial bulk and heat retention, and makes the carrier more difficult to clean and maintain.
6. Proprietary plastic for patent evasion.
Basically, it was designed by tards. The Strandhogg is probably "the best" civilian-accessible modern plate carrier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56712861
The simplest process would probably just involve purifying sulfuric acid from an acidic volcanic spring, many of which have naturally high concentrations of sulfuric acid. The second simplest would involve burning any number of sulfur-containing minerals and bubbling the gas through water, which is the procedure used historically to produce it when the chemical industry consisted entirely of burning rocks, plants, and animals in a retort. Most production processes can also use platinum as a catalyst. Vanadium oxide is preferred because Platinum can be gradually leached when producing concentrated H2SO4 at scale. Platinum can be easily obtained in the quantities necessary for catalysis, if only from scavenging the catalytic converters from rusted out automobiles.

I'd recommend at least digging through 2-3 wikipedia articles before you pretend to be a chemist.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56708791
what are you talking about, SAAMI already approved .277 fury at 80k PSI which if you tried to fire from some older .308 hunting rifles would probably fuck shit up.

.308 win is ~71.12mm OAL with a ~12.01mm cartridge rim diameter while .277 fury has a ~71.76mm OAL with a ~11.99mm cartridge rim diameter. The only real difference is the bullet shape/size and obviously the powder load. The actual .277 fury cartridge itself is remarkably similar to it's .308 parent case. The cartridge wall diameter for .277 fury is 11.71mm where the taper begins and it's 11.53mm for .308, at the base of the cartridge it's 11.94mm for .277 fury and 11.96mm for .308. The length of the cartridge from the base to the taper for .277 fury is 41.42mm and 39.62mm for .308. These differences MIGHT not allow a magazine fed .308 rifle to reliably chamber .277 fury, but you could potentially load in a single round and get it to fire potentially ruining the rifle. A modern higher-end .308 rifle would likely be able to handle an 80k PSI loading, it wouldn't be happy about it and i'd expect some extra wear and tear, but I wouldn't expect it to catastrophically fail as an older rifle might.

Would love to see someone give it a shot at some point, though I know finding .277 fury at all right now is difficult, and I don't think anyone can find an 80k PSI loading for sale even though the SAAMI spec allows it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There is no one universal answer to this because it depends entirely on you, your lifestyle, and your location.

Ask yourself the following questions:
>where do I work
>what does my workplace look like physically
>are my coworkers anti-weapon
>can I carry my EDC kit without it getting in the way of work
>what is my city's violent crime rate
>what is my city's homeless population like
>do I live around degenerates
>do I work around degenerates
>given my answers to the above, what weapons and gear should I and can I reasonably carry day to day
Once you answer those, you can assess how far away or how close you might have to defend yourself. Because of my lifestyle and my gear, the closest for me is clinching-range and the farthest is maybe 100 yards, tops.

https://iwpr.net/global-voices/chechnyas-homemade-weapons-fuel-war

Chechnya's Homemade Weapons Fuel War
Rebels are using improvised and home-made weapons to continue their guerrilla war.

Thursday, 15 April, 2004

Umalt Dudayev
On a chilly day at the beginning of April a short young man wearing a black jacket, jeans and knitted cap pulled right down to his eyes walked briskly through Grozny’s central market. He went up to two Russian officers who were buying cigarettes and beer at a small mud-spattered kiosk.


The young man suddenly pulled out a short-barrelled gun from under his jacket and opened fire on the unsuspecting Russians. Then he dropped his own gun next to the dead bodies and quickly pulled the gun of one officer out from its holster, grabbed a submachine gun lying next to the other and disappeared into a nearby side-street.


When Russian and Chechen security officials arrived at the scene some time later, no one could describe for them what the killer looked like. The only evidence they found was the abandoned Chechen-made Borz – or Wolf – submachine gun.


The Chechen-manufactured Borz is one of a number of weapons, made, reconfigured or repaired in Chechnya, which enable enemies of the Russian military and the pro-Moscow Chechen police force to continue their fight at very low cost. The net result is that even if the Russian authorities were to manage to stop the theft of weapons, or their trade and sale to the rebels, a substantial arsenal will remain in their hands.


The 9-mm submachine gun Borz is an ideal weapon for sudden attacks. It is a small compact gun, whose lightness and ease of use makes up for its poor technical quality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56695174
“This submachine gun has quite poor tactical and technical features,” said Major Anatoly Medvedev, an officer for the Russian intelligence service, the FSB, in Chechnya. “The 9-mm bullets from the Makarov pistol, which the Borz uses, are too powerful for the steel from which the gun’s barrel is made and wear it out quickly. After shooting two or three cartridges, a Borz simply begins to ‘spit’ the bullets out.


“Nonetheless, I would describe this gun as ideal for saboteurs and killers. It has entirely fulfilled its purpose as a weapon used by paramilitary groups of a partisan type. It has a fantastic rate of fire, and once all the bullets have been fired it can simply be thrown away. As far as I know, a Borz costs very little in Chechnya, about 100 US dollars, and its production requires little effort or expense.”


The Borz gun was first produced in 1992 in Grozny’s Krasny Molot factory by the order of the first Chechen president. General Jokhar Dudayev, who personally received the first manufactured weapon bearing the number, 0001. Industrial production of the gun soon stopped due to the lack of good-quality metal and the outbreak of war in 1994. But the homemade manufacture of these weapons has continued up until recently.


Vladimir Semchenko, head of the science department at Moscow’s Central Army Forces Museum of Russia, told IWPR that the main military museum of the country has several Chechen Borz submachine guns in its collection, “One of them was given to our museum as a gift by General Gennady Troshev [who formerly commanded Russian troops in Chechnya]. The exemplars of this gun that we have differ from one another both in their technical features and in appearance, which indicates that they were homemade.”


Adlan Musayev, who used to work at the Krasny Molot factory, said that “only several hundred” Borz guns were produced there but it had spawned many more copies.

Guns are nice but (many) bombs are better and simpler to produce locally. Ukrainian machine shops could spit out Stens etc but small arms don't kill armored vehicles. Claymore style IEDs can cut down formations.

WP (for smoke and destroying disabled and other vehicles), frags (preferably with launchers, PIAT style but simpler spring style have no backblast signature and make nil noise themselves), EFPs of the simple style Iran donated to Iraqi insurgents etc would be useful.

Afterwards Ukrainians could harvest Russian weapons from the dead. IED kits to detonate leftover ordnance could also be used for bomb disposal after the war. Bombs are standoff weapons which beats getting shot to pieces or having to run away in confined areas. Russians are ill equipped to defend against bombs and mines and command-detonated mines (which can be horizontal if wanted). IEDs can be left when locals withdraw.

There is no need for home made guns because they're enormous time sinks for indifferent performance. This is no larp fantasy, it's to kill and maim as many gopnigs as practical. Russia cannot churn out MRAPs easily (it lost Ukrainian steel manufacturing) and EFPs could sail through a BME laughing all the way.

This is a hunk of steel pipe with some tack welded clips holding a copper plate. A small local machine ship could churn out a hundred a day. Supply detonators of various types and you can mobility kill tanks and K-kill lesser vehicles.

posts.com:
>>56695174
>>56695188
Homemade weapons have helped Chechen rebels fight on, particularly in the second conflict that began in 1999. The fighters do not have heavy weaponry but are extremely skilful at fashioning whatever comes to hand into battle arms.

Their guerrilla warfare relies heavily on mines and explosives. Lacking conventional mines, they use unexploded mines and rockets. Sometimes they simply surround the rockets with explosive and blow them up. Often they heat the unexploded weapons over fire and obtain liquid explosive, which they pour into containers, to which they then add metal bolts, nuts and nails to create shrapnel.

The Russian high command, and especially its main spokesman Ilya Shabalkin, has frequently said that its soldiers have found medical syringes at captured militant bases and used this as proof that many fighters are drug addicts. However, it appears that most of these syringes are being used as detonators for mines. De-miners can detect metal objects but do not pick up the presence of plastic syringes.

The guerrillas are also skilled at reusing captured weaponry. Major Medvedev said they had found a heavy machine gun in a militant base in Vedeno in southern Chechnya which had been removed from the turret of an armoured vehicle. “Even those officers who had served in many conflict zones were amazed at what they saw,” he said.

“The fighters put it on a rotating tripod, fixed bicycle handlebars to it, and connected the mechanism of electric trigger to an ordinary battery. As a result they turned it into a very powerful, compact and convenient gun, which is as good as factory-made ones. As the saying in Russia goes, ‘Necessity is the mother of invention’!”

Twenty-three-year-old Iznaur, who fought in the platoon of the famous Chechen commander Hamzat Gelayev, whose death was recently confirmed, reveals another source of weaponry.

>Twenty-three-year-old Iznaur, who fought in the platoon of the famous Chechen commander Hamzat Gelayev, whose death was recently confirmed, reveals another source of weaponry.
“Turning a drive shaft from a KAMAZ truck into a mortar doesn’t take much effort,” he said. “You just need to solder a medium-sized nail to one end of the shaft, and your mortar is ready! All that’s left is to stick it into the ground and you can start shooting. We had several such mortars in our platoon.”

Attempts by pro-independence president Aslan Maskhadov to produce arms in the inter-war period of 1996-9 also created a stock of weaponry that is still being used. Weapons were produced mainly in Grozny at some of the workshops of the half-destroyed Krasnyi Molot and Elektropribor factories and in the third largest city in Chechnya, Argun. The Argun factory mainly produced mortars and grenade launchers.

An FSB officer in Chechnya, who wished to remain anonymous said, “According to our information, before they invaded Dagestan in the summer of 1999, the units of Shamil Basayev and the Arab fighter Khattab received over 250 such mortars and about a thousand auxiliary grenade launchers, which had been manufactured in Argun. Also, in Grozny, Makarov pistols were being made on a territory of a former tram depot. Components were purchased at military factories in Russia.”

Even today in Chechnya one can buy Makarov pistols, refashioned from gas pistols for between 100 and 150 dollars. Makeovers that have an “Ossetian” barrel from North Ossetia are the most popular with the buyers. They are just one part of an arsenal of weaponry that is fuelling the continuing violence in Chechnya.

Umalt Dudayev is a pseudonym of an independent Chechen journalist.

It's possible to do some weird math that you can use get a 36 target for 25.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Do you have a zeroed optic on the gun already? Because if so.
>Aquire laser bore sight and a piece of grid paper. Make a small target dot in the middle. 2x2 of the grids.
>Do the measurements and math to find where your hold would be at 25 yards with your optic.
>Put it all together. Aim the bore sight laser at the dot. Note where your optic reticle is.
If you can't figure out the next step, you just need to find a place to shoot and zero.

>>56708265
You can measure feet with your feet, that's why they're called feet. Inches are the inch of your finger as well. Get a ruler and measure your inches, whichever one is closest to a standard inch is the one you use to measure. Measure your foot while on the ground wearing shoes (unless you intend to rough measure barefoot). See how much of an overstep you have to make. A standard foot is bigger to allow overstep so you don't trip while walk measuring. Now you can rough measure distances. Yards are a big step but I don't fuck with them because it's hard to step the same distance every time.

This knowledge is suppressed to fake the superiority of the metric system. The imperial system is a better system for humans to use because every human has fingers and feet on them at all times. Not every human has a stick that's 1/5,000th of the equator, that's retarded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56704139
Currently, but they can be significantly larger and still a massive pain to defend against. Sensors can reach out miles. All they need to do is feed your location into the fire missions queue and keep eyes on you.

Meanwhile, batteries that aim and load themselves, and then fire munitions which can course correct are a nightmare. Even worse when they can scoot on their own. Smaller ground drones that can navigate following IFVs open up the door to organic small unit fire support, with 60-120mm guided mortars, and field guns on the table, or smaller missiles.

Now a squad doesn't have to try to ambush you, they just send a spotter up and have this guy following them destroy it, or if they are defending, have a mine pop up and fire a guided missile.

The problem is the rate of fire missions and massively better accuracy. Direct attack drones have a role but they were always going to be secondary once target acquisition AI got better. A tiny spotter is harder to detect and can stay up longer. IR, visual, and radar range is extremely long. Ground batteries have infinite loiter time, and when they aim themselves, you can go right from being spotted by some invisible speck in the distance to having a smart shell headed your way.

EFPs fired from shells at high velocities make interception much harder. Trajectory changes and you have a huge increase in velocity, and these things can hit a truck barreling down the road.

I've seen one video of them from Ukraine, it's quite a sight. BMP is at a cross roads in the center of the frame, nothing visible, then a lightening fast streak and the thing explodes. No catching the round in a paused frame like you might with a shell or missile.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56707524
No one thinks microwaves are going to make drones a non-issue going forward. It's more of a fantasy to think you could knock observer drones out of the sky in a 10 or even 3 mile radius than even having swarms of Sharpie sized drones out doing spotting (their battery is shit).

Microwaves will be one layer of protection but they aren't going to be able to stop target acquisition completely because that can be done from significant distances with passive sensors using fairly small drones.

What you'll need is a multilayered approach. With microwaves playing some role, lasers another, and projectile interception yet another.

The solution to target acquisition is going to have to be longer range weapons, tighter energy beams (which means finding and tracking the things, not hitting a region) or projectiles. It's also going to mean avoiding getting spotted, reducing radar signatures, and blanketing areas in IR noise to mask your position.

Of course, drones can also take advantage of noise. You can seed the sky with cheap shit, even derigibles, to make it harder to find your assets.

Eventually, as the autonomous function mature, you'll have drone interceptors as an answer for keeping your near airspace clear, which will result in a cute, autonomous mini air battle that occurs between opposing forces around concentrations.

My idea, which is maybe a bit to far fetched, is that militaries could recoup some costs by charging a hefty subscription fee to let you remote pop into one of these small drones and help take out enemy spotters or spot enemy artillery.

It would add some unpredictability to autonomous patterns and I bet people would pay well to get to pilot a small fighter in VR. You'd get streamers and autists who would learn to really push your hardware to the limit. Kids would rush home from school to make the Third Congo War nightly air offensive wait-list.

posts.name: Resident Wumbologist
posts.com:
>>56709710
The HK33 isn't significantly less effective than the AR. Biggest thing it's missing is the last round bolt hold open. Other than that it's inexpensive, accurate and reliable. It's popular with countries that primarily use and license build the G3 (such as Turkey), since they share parts and it is convenient to build them alongside the rest of the G3 family of weapon systems. Because the design and ergonomics are similar, much of the training and experience with one will cross over to the other.

As for other non-AR-15 weapon systems there are a ton of AR-18 derivatives and similar designs. Basically AR multi-lug rotating bolt locking into a barrel extension but instead of having a piston inside the bolt carrier, the carrier is a much smaller and shorter BCG pushed back by a more conventional piston (either long or short stroke). It's simpler, stays cleaner, plays nicer with different muzzle devices and suppressors, is easier to do design changes with or cater to different requirements that could be done with an AR-15 "DI" system but would be a pain in the ass to implement. The most prominent feature is being able to have a true folding stock or configure the whole design as a bullpup since the shorter bolt carrier eliminates the need for a buffer tube.

posts.com:
/arg/ Tasks of the month for Jan-2023
Maintenance-
Optics are useful on your KP-15, but they only work when you respect them, part of this is cleaning them.
>Do you have a lens blower?
>Do you have a lens brush?
>Do you have lens paper?
>Do you have lens cleaner?
How do you intend to carry this into the field with you?
You should at this point know how your optics degrade in relation to how dirty they get. Next time your optic is filthy take the opportunity to observe assorted distances at various times throughout the day to see how much clarity you lose.

Skill Sustainment-
Target: 3x3” Plate or similar paper
Rounds: 20-40 rounds
Equipment: Rifle w/ KP-15 lower (WWSD also approved)
After confirming zero at 100yd walk back to 600yd.
Action: Upon buzzer start standing @ low ready (real low ready, not wgws low ready), Drop to a knee and deliver thirty solid hits on the 9x9 plate and call your time. Add 10 seconds for each dropped shot
Total times (time+dropped penalty):
>Cold 3 sec = Par
>Warmed up 4 sec = par
>6 and below = cooking it
Record your times and experiment with the mag level on your KP-15.

Improvement-
If you are using a harris or similar force to overcome style bipod you can improve deployment speed with a quick mod at home.
Get a 12” long piece of paracord and tie an overhand knot over itself 3 times in the center, some people like to leave a tail on longer guns. Grab one end of the line and tie it to a harris bipod leg above the release button with a suitable knot, repeat on the other leg. To deploy; pinch the knot or grasp the line that dangles between the legs when folded and yank down with a jerk motion. It will deploy both legs at once and doesn’t require you to reach across the bipod or juggle the gun when prone. More documentation: https://ridgelineshooting.com/bipod-paracord-hack/ and https://youtu.be/21Azmj0rJQ0 [Embed]

Post task of month times/feedback in thread

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56711314
So, I built both the uppers with triarc rails, got all the bullshit for that at the last garage sale. The one with the bootleg lower has a 11.5" bbl with carbine length gas, but a suppressed port, so it would never work unsuppressed anyways. That wasn't surprising, everything is operating as designed there, he just doesn't need the fancy bcg because it's already reduced.

The G railed gun has a DD 11.5" barrel with their carbine length gas. Afterwards during the autopsy, we noticed it has about a .065-67" port, when I was expecting a fat boi since DDs were notoriously overgassed. It seems that has changed with newer barrels. It still ran like a top with a can tho.

The other upper I built with garage sale parts, it has a 12.5 bbl with a midlength gas. That one has been a pain to get working, since the dude I sold it to doesn't have a can. When I checked the port on that, it was at .075". I may end up opening that up a bit to .080 and seeing if that fixes things.

Everything acted severely undergassed. Even swapping buffer weights did nothing, when they actually ejected it was just a flop to the right about 2-3'.

posts.name: A2Grip

>>56712235
>Clean CH and Upper free of oil/junk
>Take upper and coat back of upper with wax
>Lock bolt back
>Pull CH back until its just about to unlatch from the upper and stop
>Squirt red (not black) RTV in there
>Shape it a little bit and wipe it down a bit
>Wait a full 24hr before touching gun
Usually the wax will prevent you from needing to run a razor between upper and seal but you can do it if you want to be cautious.

I have seen prominent video game youtubers for example pay Ukraine for one of their shells. People are putting doges on armored vehicles. Memes are genuinely impacting the conflict. How do you think net culture will impact future military operations? Will we see combat livestreams with donations and subs? Literal stream sniping in retaliation? Twitch chat bit gambles on which squad takes the most territory? E-celeb mercenaries with a kill count?

We've seen videos of ukie command centers using Microsoft Teams and Google Meet for the live viewing of drone footage.

There's a final factor that this combat footage has tactic approval of the Ukrainian goverment, which might not be the case elsewhere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56709031
>Pic
That poor, poor PBF. They don't deserve such horrible fate

As of OP's question, get a PMK-2, a long hose meant for GP-5 and several of the big, old filters (but make sure they were properly stored. They should not smell like fungus and/or ammonia). Why the hose? Because your neck will hurt like hell after just 3 hours with a filter on your face
After that, get an OZK. It's old, it's uncomfortable, will give you a heat stroke, but it does protect against the stuff you don't want in your skin and it's cheap
Alternatively, get thick a neck-entry catsuit on bright&shiny ))
If you are really paranoid and want to be able to walk really long distance, get a drinking adapter for PMK (should be included in the kit, but it's sometimes left out. Looks like a green flask cap with a connector), corresponding soviet military flask for it and a 1-2 Rearz Barnyard. You'll need to drink a lot, and not all of that water will come out as sweat. Just put one on before putting on the OZK, and you're golden

I do own an M14gery, but I wouldn't leave it on display in my car because then I'd be out a gun worth well over 1.5k.

As a general rule, leaving valuable things in plain view in your car is a bad idea. If you live in an area where you feel it's safe to do so then you do you, but that merely reduces the odds of a break-in. It doesn't eliminate them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: My next-most uncommon rifle is a Portuguese Mauser-Vergueiro still in the original full Model 1904 length and 6.5x58mm caliber. 100,000 made from 1905-1907, in the late 1930s some ~66,000 of those that still remained were converted to short rifles in 8x57mm. Many of the surviving long rifles on the US market show markings from Portuguese East Africa colonial service; this one doesn't.

Pic rel is rarest. 1 of 200 FN 1924 carbine for an Argentine provincial police force. I have a fairly rare group of Argentines, minus the academy rifles which are a goal eventually. I'll reply with another.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56697227
>>56697240
The 1935 rifle is another rare in correct config. If you have the Webster book his assertion that the Argentine 1935 is an FN Mle1935 is wrong. This contract never happened, and the 1935 Argentine rifles are identical to the 1933 Buenos Aires police Mausers other than them being marked with the national crest vs Buenos Aires Policia. The complete 1935 rifles are sometimes marked with Buenos Aires police markings, so I believe they were also police contracts. According to some documents from Mauser there were like 2-3k rifles and some replacement actions. My gun is matching serials on the bolt and receiver. Barrel is a MM.
